Can you blame an anime for having too much... anime in it?
Perhaps not, but Zetsuen no Tempest tried its dardnest to convince me of it. I do not by that mean that it has a sickening over-abundance of weathered shonen tropes, overt fanservice, cringeworthy harem setups and moe everywhere you look - it has some of these things to moderate extents, but not enough that it feels bad. Nor is it the fact that that quotes and references classical literature are a dime a dozen; a feature all too familiar with those who enjoy more philosophical and ponderous animes (and perhaps fiction in general), andone which does work within certain frameworks and in moderate amounts, but usually, as ends up the case with Tempest, winds up as a contrived and counter-productive attempt at appearing edgy and smart, leaving the overarching work with a bitter taste of pseudo-intellectuality.


No, in fact, Tempest surprised me by having a series of opening episodes that actually pulled me in and left me intrigued, by playing out the setup in a very fascinating manner, leaving little breathing room as you gradually get a sense of a bleak situation that leaves the necessary blanks, aided by animation and music that sets up just the right tone - something Bones has a fairly decent track record with. Indeed as the plot unfolds and unravels to the viewer, we are treated to a handful of very nice twists; some are expected but none the less engaging whilst others come as a bit of a surprise, one that makes sense in hindsight, as any good twist should. The characters as introduced appear multi-layered and there's a lot that's said by nothing being said in terms of interaction and emotion.


And then... it all sort of fizzles out, not after fifteen episodes or half the series but alrady seven-eight or so episodes in it had become clear which direction it was headed, and it was not a particularly good one; I was wondering every time I was about to open the next episode. I kept hoping it didn't lose the tempo and the mood it had created - certainly, any mysterious fog about characters and the plot is bound to unravel, but it can be done elegantly or bluntly, done well or done poorly, and in some ways it did manage to keep going and hold strong to what it did well, what set it apart (and in a good sense at that) but more and more it departed and became more.... well, anime-like.


To be specific, then, as I already excluded what I meant by this statement, let me elaborate on what I include in this statement.


First, let it be said: Zetsuen no Tempest is a story about people, who range from the completely ordinary to born with a special destiny, each is faced with carrying the fate of the world on their back to some extent or another, but choose instead to disregard this in favour of acting entirely on their own, personal reasons. People who choose revenge or love over saving the world, or finding meaning in a loved one's death. It is a very interesting angle to start with, as we are usually treated to people who without hesitation tend to accept that they must, indeed, save the world above their personal priorities. To a certain extent, the characters of Zetsuen do this, particularly as time goes on and they learn to cope with their circumstances and come to terms with reality, but they remain personally - emotionally - motivated, which serves a different angle, as indeed many people would not readily say "OK, I'll save the world" when presented with such a daunting task, at least not without secondary motivation.


On the other hand, these personal and deeply emotional motivations often find themselves stranded in a vacuum. They are is repeatedly portrayed with an illogical sort of unreasonableness; not just one that can be waved away with basis in the fact that emotions are by nature unreasonable. Rather, it approaches a level of nonsensicality that extends quite beyond the scope of the human condition, it becomes a rather wishy-washy and forced excuse for the characters acting on their own impulses and not caring about saving the world (even though they deep down do), again suffering from the sort of assumed edginess that endless quotes of Shakespearian works are symptomatic of. It is the sort of unreasonableness that is often seen in anime characters as their initial defining characteristics, such as acting only for love or revenge, are taken far beyond their logical conclusion, indeed, even past the often extreme points that revenge can take one - or rather than talking about moving past it ends up becoming something entirely different of a sort, still portrayed as a desire for revenge or love but stooped to a put-on and uncohesive mess that falls on its own rambling, particularly as we are treated to a set of increasingly strained exchanges towards the climax of the first act. It loses aim and purpose in a sense; that is, the plot still knows its direction but the characters and themes feel lost in some sort of hollow vacuum manufactured separate from the narrative, in order to defend their increasingly contrived stances. And, yet, in a twist of irony, it also completely forgoes these stances at times when the story deems it convenient, oft bereft of any explanation.


After this, the second arc ends up being, for the most part, an increasing anticlimax where any sort of pull the story originally had becomes lost, washed away in favour of increasingly, well, anime-esque elements. As the heroine, Hakaze, asks herself in a moment of authorial self-deprecation: "Is this some sort of romantic comedy?" Unfortunately, making a joke at your own expense does not excuse shoddy work. It is not just the "rom-com" aspects as much as how everyone starts to act more towards anime stereotypes, the standards are more conformed to, scenes and themes and indeed even jokes alternating between the self-regurgitating nonsense, as previously described, and increasingly common anime tropes. It at once manages to depart from that which in a good way set it apart in faovur of the mundane, and also completely soil those more unique aspects, turning it on its head to something that kind of just leaves a bad aftertaste.


So, to re-ask my original question: Can it be blamed for too much an anime, for conforming to its own medium? My gut answers no, and I don't really, but unfortunately it showed a lot of excellent ways to stand apart from the rest early on, only to have that descend into utter banality and near-parodic mirroring of its once-great aspects. And I will not forgive it for introducing butt-monkey character Hanemura, who ironically ends up being almost the most relatable of the bunch at a time when the rest have long since departed any sense of reason or insight. Even so, the late introduction out of nowhere, while perhaps expected of a second arc, does not work in his favour and he feels way too weak and irrelevant a character to have the role that he has thrust upon him.


And, yet, it still offers up the occasional well-placed dialogue or development, even as it goes on, and Yoshino remains an interesting character almost entirely throughout, as one who actually offers some semblance of realism in his approach to situations and particularly his emotional development is interesting to watch. The flashbacks with him and Aika are also highly enjoyable, though Aika is the main "beneficiary" of the frequent Shakespeare references, putting her on the put-on edginess pedestal. It should be said that the parallels to characters and themes from the relevant works of Shakespeare do sometimes work heavily in the show's favour, but mostly it falls flat and you are left wondering why it even matters. Mahiro on the other hand is an incredibly dull character, the "cool guy" stereotype with an added flavour of revenge to make a very overused form of anti-hero


In the end, Zetsuen no Tempest is an anime that tries, that really tries, to do something good and different, and it almost succeeds but seems to stumble in its own feed as it gets going, which is such a shame, for it started out well. The one highly praisable thing is the soundtrack, and at times the animation, which helps set the mood it needs, but that, too, often fails its job. Most of the second half of the first arc could easily have been condensed into perhaps two episodes, and most of the second arc could have been cut entirely, or condensed equivalently, which would have lent the series the pacing and tempo it would have needed to maintain that excellent mood it sets right off the bat but quickly departs from as it descends into all-too-familiar territory.

Zetsuen no Tempest's driving focus plays out like some bad drama that you mother watches her free holiday mornings. The absurdity of Mahiro's obsession and Yoshino's secrets would be at home in any Shakespeare plays. 
Like Shakespearean works, the major draw here are the characters. While they may be extreme examples of human personalities, they never lose their believably. You find yourself drawn into their world and rooting for their success.
The story, while prone to cliche, is nonetheless interesting and immersive. The individual motivations and struggles of Mahiro, Yoshino, and Hakaze form a nice balance in the foreground of a story in which the wholeworld is upheaved. Throw in a few twists, some smart dialogue reminiscent of Death Note and you have a story sure to entertain.\n\n
While I can't really pass this off a complete review due to the incomplete nature of the narrative, I highly doubt I will rank this anime lower at the end.\n\n

Zetsuen no Tempest tries to create something profound and moving but ultimately falls flat on its face. It's flashy, creative, and 'claims' that it draws inspiration from the works of William Shakespeare, mainly Hamlet, Romeo and Juliet, and The Tempest, and I get why - the best Tragedy, the best Romance, and Shakespeare's final work all have powerful undertones and are infinitely quotable. The problem is, well, everything else.
First, the plot. It's the element that everyone praises about this show, so I'll give it special attention here. Mahiro (Hamlet) and Yoshino (Romeo) are best friends, but the death of Mahiro's sister Aika (Caliban / Juliet,I'm pretty sure) sends Mahiro over the edge and his lust for vengeance divides the two. Then, Mahiro finds a message in a bottle that allows him to communicate with Hakaze (Prospero), a powerful mage who promises to find Aika's killer if Mahiro helps her get back at her own family for throwing her on a desert island. Fair enough.


It's the part where characters people are turning inexplicably to metal, government agents with shotguns attack Yoshino, and giant 'fruit' start popping out of the earth and ocean that everything starts to go wrong. I say 'fruit', because that's what the show calls them. In reality, they're giant rocks with eyeballs popping out and trees on top, plus a couple giant chains stuck to them that get yanked out of the ground with them. Did I mention that they appear in the dozens at a time and fly through the air? Yeah, this show is weird.


Crazy is a natural part of anime - some of my favorites are the wackier ones - but the problems arise when none of these events are explained except in the loosest of terms, and after about three episodes of action and plot, the show comes to a SCREECHING halt. About three episodes in a row are spent almost entirely in flashbacks, mainly illustrating how Aika was a crazy horny b*tch with... well, I won't spoil it. But it shatters the pacing completely and gives essentially no meaningful insight into the characters.


So, Story is a 4/10 - it tries really hard to be several things at once (action, psychological, dramatic, occasionally comedic) and it backfires SPECTACULARLY.



Artistic style in Zetsuen no Tempest is very good, honestly, not much you can knock it for. It's pretty, it's effective, and it feels distinct from other similar shows. The only drawback is the occasional overuse of certain repeating scenes (like the chanting at the Magic Tree). 8/10.



Sound design is a controversial element for the show - it uses a lot of classical music, which I find fits the show perfectly, and had my blood pumping quite a lot. However, the melodramatic music when they're showing how nuts Aika is for the 47th time, or the tension they try to build when Mahiro acts like a psychopath AGAIN gets old very, very quickly. The best moments hit a 9/10 easily, but the worst are a 5/10, so 7/10 seems like a good compromise.



Character design in Zetsuen no Tempest is, well, pretty terrible. Their characters are 'inspired' by Shakespearean protagonists, but in truth it's only in the loosest of terms. Mahiro lacks the core qualities of Hamlet - his indecisiveness, his pensiveness, the resentment and guilt that make him such a compelling character. Mahiro is your typical Shonen hero, reckless with a devil-may-care attitude and a chaotic rhythm to his behavior, and that's fine, but it's NOT BLOODY HAMLET.


Yoshino is Romeo only in that he had a tragic romance, but Romeo is defined by his ability to bounce back after a bad breakup (Rosaline at the beginning of the play, I believe). He's passionate, optimistic, and is lead by his heart, not his head. In contrast, Yoshino is a cool, calculating and dour figure who is defined by apathy and his ability to outsmart his opponents. So, not Romeo in the slightest. I could go on, but I assume you got the gist. 6/10, for not following their inspiration in the SLIGHTEST, and for reverting to type instead. You could replace the protagonists with Natsu and Gray from Fairy Tail, or Ichigo and Ishida from Bleach and you wouldn't notice much.



Enjoyment is a sticky category. You see, I still enjoyed the everloving HELL out of this anime, for the most part. My girlfriend grinned every time they quoted Shakespeare, and there was a lot of unintentional comedy with some of the shots. One quick shot of a cat turned into metal with a weird expression had us in fits for the rest of the episode, and the fact that I anticipated ALL of the plot twists by basically saying whatever I thought was the most ridiculous thing I could think of at that moment led to no end of fun. 8/10, because fun is fun no matter what.



Overall, the show merits a 7/10, Good. The visual and sound design are attractive distractions from the silly plot, overblown drama, and flying-rock-eyeball-fruit-things, but if you're looking for depth and a compelling narrative, look elsewhere.

Now it might sound very cliché that these two teenagers are on a travel to save the world, but luckily the series does it very well in that regard.
I can start of mentioning the two lesser good things about Zetusen no Tempest:
1. Fuwa Mahiro. One of the main protagonists. At times, he can be too much of a hot-blooded shounen character. Rushes straight into matters with simple and brute solutions, fueled by the emotion of revenge. While this is a good counterpart to the other protagonist and his friend, the intelligent and methodical Takigawa Yoshino, Mahiro's personality can be a bit clichéd and predictable attimes, but he also has his good moments.


2. The first few episodes. While I never got a feeling that the pacing of the these first episodes was never rushed, the plot progressed kinda slow. It's not a big issue, but I feel like there could be a slight improvement here. However, this allowed more time to get to know the characters and the situation of the world. It just would be swell if there was a perfect balance between the amount of exposition and plot progression. But after those few episodes, things start to heat up pretty fast!


Now for the good stuff:


- Story: As already mentioned, the whole teenagers-out-to-save-the-world-thing is old as hell, but the way it was executed was rather surprising and unconventional in a good way. You know those typical solutions of typical shounen characters? The ones where they pull a superpower or something similar out of their asses and suddenly the problem is solved? Well, nothing of that here! Here we actually have characters that fight equally with superpowers and words. While the action parts can be entertaining to watch, it is the clever fights with words that steal the show. Words that are carefully crafted with logic, reasoning and lies can even have the power to the turn the tide of a conflict. That itself is something few animes (and far less in shounen animes) can do well, and well Zetsuen no Tempest does.


- Art: I dare say that the art surpassed the manga version. It has a lot cleaner look and emphasized the characters' personalities better than in the manga. Seeing how the drawer for the manga was responsible for the character design of the anime, it isn't too odd, really. Luckily, the production value of this part is a lot higher than your average shounen anime. And for that, I am glad, for Zetusen no Tempest truly deserves it. As far I noticed, there were no cheap shortcuts for the animation and such. The series has a quality feel to it.


- Sound: The music. Without a doubt, the most surprising part of the anime. Here I was expecting somewhat generic music to accompagny the art and story. But boy, was I wrong. The exception is the first opening song. While it isn't necessary a bad song on its own, but it doesn't match too well of the tone of the anime. My favorite track of Zetsuen no Tempest is without the second opening song ("Daisuki na no ni" by Kylee). It's a catchy and beautiful song with lyrics that fit with the show. Other than that, the show has music that fits with the mood, created with real instruments rather than computer-generated. It really helps set the mood of the moments of the show.


- Characters: I already mentioned the bad things about Fuwa Mahiro, so I'll let that be. But the real star of the show is his friend Takigawa Yoshino. Even just a high-schooler, he is a rather intelligent individual that would rather fight with words and wit than brawn and might. Overall a cool and composed character that is hard to not like. The other characters can be a hit or miss. Just about all characters you meet, are in some way used in future episodes and not just "thrown away" like they tend to do in other shounen series. However, some of them don't add too much than other characters. This is more of a nitpick from my side.


So overall, a great series. Too bad the anime didn't cover the epilogue that the manga had. Let's hope they produce this if many enough people enjoy the show! ^^

A very good anime that, despite messy backstory and unclear concept, redeems itself with great characters, artistry and music.

surprisingly, this did not feel very shounen-like. yes, we have teenagers who save the world withmagic, but it is really far from the standard fare that can be described with that synopsis.  really, we do not actually have any heroes here for most of the anime. the shakespeare angle is also not something you'd normally expect in shounen.


what i liked:  the art.  detailed, interesting, original, fluid animation.  the sound was supportive of the mood.  the mystery part of the story was interesting, well enough developed to keep me watching, and i could figure out what was going on (this is rare in anime, which generally does mystery badly).  the shakespearean aspect of the story was ambitious, and i liked the idea of using the different revenge stories to compare and contrast.  the magic rules as originally introduced were nifty.  the relationship between aika and yoshino was very interesting.  there were battles but they were not interminable (yay; my least favourite part of shounen is the constant battling).


what i didn't like:  the abrupt change for the worse in just about everything but art/animation/sound in the second half. the pacing went from slow to erratic and counter-productive.  i never got the sense that this world was actually in danger.  what could have been a fascinating development of how former enemies might become allies was wasted, and there was not enough character development for supporting cast who initially looked promising.  there was way too much exposition in the second half.  the plot around how hakaze got to the island and how/why she had prepared hidden talismans had holes large enough to plant a giant Tree of Confusion.  as did the plot -- what plot? of the government reacting to the exodus fruit.  lots of lost opportunity here for creating more emotional tension.  last but not least hakaze went from a strong female character who kept up her spirits while on a deserted island to a stupid-in-love blushing maiden always embarrassed, who, instead of thinking about the serious matters ahead thought only about luv,luv,luv. in fact i would have been fine if there had been no romance whatsoever between hakaze and yoshino; i don't believe in it, yoshino is too deadened to realistically respond, and it falls completely flat; i do not even want to see them together. 


what i am torn about: the shakespeare quotes were too random and often ended up feeling pretentious rather than integral to the story; the whole mashup is rather tenuous and i often felt like opportunity was lost to really draw parallels.  character development was uneven for the two male leads mahiro and yoshino, leaving in the end only one solid character, aika, who didn't have much screen time, which means even about her we're missing a lot of motivation.  for large parts of the story it seemed the characters' actions did doesn't actually matter, and while i am sure that was purposeful (shakespearean actors on a stage following their prescribed roles), it didn't gel for me, and therefore the resolution fizzled.  yoshino:  i like him, he's probably the most complex character of them all.  but while i understand why he is detached at the start, he remains too remote.


in short, this started well and the mystery held up, but the world saving was a bust.  i still enjoyed myself, but i am also left feeling somewhat empty now that it's done.

I ventured to watch this anime with expectations quite high since I was intrigued by the synopsis. At times it came up to my scratch, at time it didn't, and finally when I finished watching it, here's what I have to say.
Story - 7
In a nutshell, Yoshino a childhood "friend" of Mahiro follows him in his quest to find the killer of his mysteriously murdered young sister Aika, in the meantime in order to find the killer Mahiro had made a deal with a real mage, and side effects of this deal include saving the world and traveling through time. It's an original formula, thoughit does pretend to be more than it actually is; still it does its job and keeps you in suspense for a while.


Lets be clear, this anime consists of two separate halves, first 12 or so episodes, and the rest episodes afterward. First half of the story is quite thrilling and closely resembles a detective story in fact: here are two childhood friends, a mysteriously murdered "sister", bizarre phenomena that turn whole towns into graveyards of iron and agents of magic. There's the tragic music, and citing from Hamlet and Tempest by Shakespeare and otherwise romanticist stuff including time paradoxes and so on.  And would have been desirable if it continued in the same spirit, yet the second half falls victim to awkward romcom. There is significantly less action, but more long-winded dialogue that doesn't contribute much to the character development and as a result that acute feeling of impending dramatic events is distilled.


Art - 9


Quite beautiful clean style, with spectacular design for magic spells. The animation is good enough, smooth and consistent throughout the series; it looks especially great during action scenes.


Sound - 7


The music has some dramatic tunes, quite to fit in the whole Shakespeare theme. I won't call it particularly stunning because it wasn't exactly memorable. I disliked most of OP and ED songs, save for those rendered by Nothing's Carved in Stone, because to my mind they didn't quite fit to overall mood of the series and strikingly fell out of picture.


Character - 8


The characters of Yoshino, Mahiro and Aika in Zetsuen no Tempest are pretty much the key elements to the plot. As implied in the series, they represent the characters from Shakespeare's plays, Hamlet which is a tragedy and Tempest which has a happy end. And throughout the series they have to strive to win their happy ending. Aika's character undoubtedly is the driving force behind the plot. Though not apparent in the beginning, her true importance and real extent of her power will blossom in later episodes. The secondary characters aren't anything special and mostly appear for comic relief or plot narration.



Overall - 7.5


It was quite enjoyable experience despite it being a little long-winded at times. If you are a fan of magic and time paradoxes, then this anime is right for you.

Hello, people! I'm here to bring you a review of what is one of my favourite anime, Blast of Tempest (Zetsuen no Tempest)
The tl;dr version: Blast of Tempest was able to tell an exciting adventure, filled with twists and turns around the mechanics of the universe. The main characters were al well developed and characterized over the course of the series, and the cast in general was a refreshing way of using common shounen characteristics. However, as much as I liked the show, its second half wasn't nearly as good as the first was. Finally, the art and animation were great as well, as bothdelivered fantastic imagery and action scenes. Now for the actual review!


Story

9/10


This story revolves around two different subplots, one of the MC's quest for revenge and the battle of two different magical Gods (the Trees - Tree of Genesis and Tree of Exodus)


The first aspect I want to bring up is the mystery and fantasy component of the series. Something that I love about fantasy in anime is when the mechanics behind it are a mystery that get well explained later on. Which is something Blast of Tempest achieved with top marks. Right in beginning, we are able to see some weird occurrences around the magic of each Tree. The way magic works in the show is revealed in the most shocking way, completely turning around what you thought you knew about it. However, most mysteries are explained in the first half of this show, which means most of the twists were also done in this first half, so the second half was more lackluster.


The next aspect is the action, it is an aspect I don't really feel passionate about in anime in general, so I'll cut down to the chase. The battle scenes were mostly short and well presented, with some great battle sequences and interesting strategies to win the fight. Again, I can't say much about it since it's not exactly my cup of tea.


Finally, the drama and the romance aspect of this series. The drama was really great, as it resolved each of the main cast's life issues and problems  in a well-written manner without having unnecessary scenes (by which I mean scenes specifically done to try to get you crying). What I wasn't too fond of, however, was the romance it threw in the second half. It was what put down this half the most, as there were a lot of scenes that featured one of the strong-hearted characters going head-over-heels with the MC which, in my opinion, went against the tone of the show.


Characters

8.5/10


The main cast of this show would be: Yoshino, Hakaze, Mahiro and Aika.


Now, one thing that I have to congratulate this show for, would be its main cast. Each individual character is unique, and not in a way it has a certain quirk that makes them funny and somewhat memorable, but because the characterization they had throughout the whole show made us see just how they are, made us understand, not only their motives, but to be capable of understanding their feeling towards a certain something.


On the more particular side of things, Yoshino, one of the male protagonists, had some seriously good development. He started out as an emotionless character (not literally of course). A character that, at the beginning, didn't seem to have all that much goals that he wanted to accomplish. When he started to fight to save the world, many characters around him were wondering just why he was doing it. But, as we see more and more of him, we start to understand the motives behind what he did. And then came the development after a certain talk, at which point he started to actually cry and have more emotions.


We also have the supportive cast. It's here that there are some problems in the character department. While we have Fraulein Yamamoto, Hanemura and Samon were all well characterized and had interesting personalities, other characters of this supporting cast didn't have their deserved moments. There were characters in this show that played a great part in the final outcome, yet they were never given much attention, which is what put this part down the most.


Final thing worth noting is the character interactions and dialogue. A lot of the show is actually spent with the characters talking to each other. Not exactly in a Monogatari sort of way, since it's not at the same level, but the exchanges were still a very nice touch. Not to mention that whenever Aika's on scene prepare for some Shakespear quotes.


Art/Animation

9/10


Blast of Tempest has delivered really good and detailed frames, but there is one particular frame that I absolutely adore. The anime, between other feats, made one of the most artistic death scenes I've seen in an anime. The particular way it was detailed, the red blood contrasting with the rest of the frame, I could go on.


The animation is also really good as well, as the action sequences were all very detailed and without any immediate flaws.


Enjoyment

9/10


Now, here's the thing about Blast of Tempest, because even though the story is quite amazingly wriiten and the characters are well developped, it still has that Shounen light. It has the character that acts without thinking and goes head-first into danger; the wimpy character that later goes stronger; the nakama power-ups; and the light-hearted fanservice humour. The anime is able to pick the right moments to be funny, resulting in one of the truest quotes and an incredibly enjoyable show altogether.


Notes

This show is available on Hulu and Crunchyroll

Zetsuen no Tempest is a perfect example of why I watch anime. It's a phenomenal representation of the medium, showing how deep and powerful the genre can be. As I review this, it has become my 2nd favorite anime of all time in a list surrounded by big names such as Fullmetal Alchemist Brotherhood and Steins;Gate. 
The 1st thing worth noting starting off this review is how amazing this story is. It's the tale of two boys and their own specific journeys while they work together to save the world. Interestingly enough, while they do plan on saving the world, their motivations are much morepowerful than a generic anime hero's decision to protect everyone and is instead a display of how different people respond to the death of a loved one. At the same time, we're introduced to a girl, a mage and princess left in a barrel and sent to an island, who aids them from afar. This story is so unique while relying on the idea of tragedy, specifically Shakespeare's work.


The primary reason why I loved the story was how it played out. Nothing feels rushed, everything goes at a logical pace and the best part of the show is a 4 episode part in which the three protagonists and an enemy of theirs work to prove their respective hypotheses (That may sound like it'd be too wordy and boring but it is masterfully engaging). 


The second aspect of the show which must be discussed is the characters which were some of the best I've seen from such a large cast since FMA Brotherhood. 1st We have Yoshino Takigawa, a quiet boy in high school who is seemingly not phased by anything. However behind this outward appearance is a damaged person trying to properly process the death of someone he loved. This approach to the character was very engaging to watch and I loved every second of his character arc, particularly the flashbacks he has. His dealing with grief is very real and sympathetic but by the end of the series, his growth is so measurable while not blatantly in the viewer's face. 


The 2nd character to note is Mahiro Fuwa, an angry teenager given the ability to use magic from a mysterious princess and mage named Hakaze. His development is arguably just as strong as Yoshino's due to his very different handling of death. He seeks vengeance and holds resentment at the world for the loss of his beloved younger sister, going as far as to agree to help save the world with Hakaze in exchange for having the killer be found. This juxtaposition of vengeance alongside Yoshino's handling of grief really helps the viewer see these characters and their differences, making scenes with them interesting to watch.


Our 3rd and last main character I need to refer to is Hakaze Kusaribe. As previously mentioned, she is the infamous mage/princess left in a barrel and sent onto an island. She works as the "odd-man out" in the series by having her work with the other two who are so deeply connected, allowing for an outsider's perspective can be shown. She deeply cares for those around her and is driven by her morals, making her a very lovable female protagonist. 


On a side note I'm going to make a comment that provides spoilers so skip ahead.



******SPOILERS******


I loved the Yoshino and Hakaze pairing so much throughout the second half and am so glad they get together at the end. While I did like Yoshino and Aika together, I loved this pairing we got in the second half as well the message the show gave us: You have to move on. While Yoshino did love Aika, him living his entire life alone because of it is just too bitter an idea for me to swallow. The scenes with Yoshino and Hakaze were great and I'm glad that this show did not do one of the worst taboos in anime, where the other love interest gets screwed over and she's okay with it. Yoshino and Hakaze were a fantastic pairing and I was panicking with the amount of time left they had to put them together at that ending, I was so afraid nothing would happen but leave it to bones to save the day.

"Zetsuen no Tempest" has currently been a fun ride- it's mysterious, engaging, and unique. 
The first half of the story is focused mainly on four characters: Yoshino, Mahiro, Hakaze, and Samon. The story is set up in a way so the audience can't identify the main plot for the first several episodes. But the way this is done is perfect- it helps keep the viewer curious. 
[Story]
The two main characters, Yoshino and Mahiro, try to help the Princess of the Kusaribe clan, Hakaze, escape an island to which she was exiled to. Through objects called "talismans" they are able to communicate with Hakaze with thepower of magic. A member of the Kusaribe clan named "Samon" quickly finds out about their intentions to free Hakaze from the island and sends out his familiars to stop Yoshino and Mahiro. Samon sent Hakaze to the empty island due to a family disagreement about the revival of a omnipresent and omniscient entity, known as the "Tree of Exodus"- which can possibly and ultimately bring the downfall to humanity.


Mahiro's deal for helping Hakaze is that Hakaze will identify the killer of Mahiro's deceased sister- Aika, so Mahiro can exact revenge. Mahiro's best friend, Yoshino, agrees to help him on his journey. But when Samon's lackeys fail to stop the duo, Samon approaches Mahiro and Yoshino himself and persuades them to leave the site of the revival of the tree. Here's where several problems occur with the first half of the story...


-The story drags on a bit too long here. Many flashback scenes about Aika, Yoshino and Mahiro, could have all been condensed into an episode or two.   

-Yoshino, Mahiro, and Samon discuss and argue for several episodes straight until the midway point of the anime. The first several episodes bring out fast-paced chases, fights, etc. But all of a sudden at some point there's a huge halt and from there the series begins to progress slowly. 

-While some scenes were necessary, others were not.


However, the second half of the story is terrific, a new character is introduced, and past characters are being more involved in the plot. Enemies have become allies and the plot begins to pick up fast from here (there's even some romance). A lot of twists, reveals, and character development begin in the second half and it's great. The second half still focuses on one main thing- the reveal of Aika's killer- but it also begins to focus on the big picture. 


[Art and Sound]

I'll keep this part short and simple- the art is fantastic, all the characters are drawn well and the animating is perfect. Every character is eye-candy to one or another. The climatic effects are amazing and overall, there's nothing wrong here. 

The opening/endings are decent but nothing glorious. The sound effects are nice and Mahiro's voice actor portrays his character very well.  


[Character] 

Yoshino is a rather bland character- although there is some character reveal about him later on in the series, he maintains a constant personality. He's a good guy, intelligent, and is kind but a bit boring for a main character. 

Mahiro, on the other hand, is brash, and also somewhat intelligent. Just like in Hamlet, Mahiro doesn't care what happens to the world as long as he gets his revenge. While his intentions are mostly straightforward, he's one of the more interesting characters in the show. He isn't complex, but he's usually calculating solutions and possibilities in his mind while Yoshino is also conjuring interesting thoughts, ideas, and some lies on his own. 


Hakaze is smart, calculating, and confident. Eventually she develops a crush on Yoshino and although that's a bit unfortunate for her character, something like this has to happen in every anime. Samon is seen mostly as the antagonist for the first half, but is later revealed to be more of an antihero. He uses dirty tricks to do what he thinks must be done. Aika, is a character shrouded in mystery and is mostly seen through flashbacks. Although she remains a key point to the plot, her character still seems a bit insignificant in regards to the story- well, it seems so until you reach the start of the climax.


[Enjoyment]

If you're looking for an action-packed anime, you're not going to find it here. The romance aspect is important in regards to several characters personalities, intentions, etc, but it is not the main focus of the show. But if you're into mystery animes, then this is for you. And like I said before, "Zetsuen no Tempest has currently been a fun ride- it's mysterious, engaging, and unique." 


The show IS mysterious. 

It IS engaging once you get into the plot. 

And it IS definitely unique in a lot of aspects. 


Overall- 8.

A lot of the "big moments" in those story threads come when one of the people involved is out ofthe room. 


That being said, the show has a lot of strong points. Animation is crisp and on-model throughout, with lots of attention paid to facial expression and use of color. The first half of the show is deliciously suspenseful, and the fight scenes are nothing to sneeze at. Big Bonus: none of these characters are a cliche. Despite some plot holes and a weaker second half, this is a good series for anyone who enjoys character interaction, psychological intrigue, and references to classic literature, as well as a fairly uplifting ending.

Blast Of Tempest was created in the crux of Bones’ downfall as a competent studio, so even though the show starts out as a polished Ufotable shounen with better pacing, it only takes a few hours for the polish to disappear and the entire show to collapse in its own confusion. It is common knowledge in the anime community that Bones lost steam after the reboot of Fullmetal Alchemist and has since been unable to reach the consistency of their previous quality when animating television shows. Blast Of Tempest, initially a big project for the studio and an anticipated show for seasonal viewers, left audiencessplit and cemented the struggle for animation company to regain their powerhouse status.


The show follows a couple of highschool friends, one of whom is dealing with the recent murder of his sister while the other is dealing with the recent death of his girlfriend. You can connect the dots. One of the friends miraculously gets in touch with a girl stranded on an island who calls herself the princess of Genesis, unveiling a hidden world of warring mages who worship the trees of Exodus and Genesis. The mages of Exodus are currently reviving their dead tree, posing a threat to humanity itself as entire city populations are mysteriously turning to iron mannequins, and the friends get mixed up in the power struggle between the two clans.


For a show aiming to present silly shounen fantasy nonsense like this in a more realistic, gritty light, Blast Of Tempest surprisingly makes it work well enough in the first act. Exposition unfolds in an engaging way as solid pacing and well-directed action suck the viewer in. The explanation of the supernatural elements is also fairly interesting, again, resembling a Ufotable Type/Moon work. Sky high production values and a good musical score created a cinematic treat as the anime began on a high note.


After an hour, however, the show starts to lose momentum as we realize that the characters aren’t interesting enough to carry the narrative. Developments in the story eventually converge and meet at a two hour scene in which the writers effectively dig their own graves, craft their own tombstones, and lay themselves down to be buried. Let’s take a closer look.


While a military assault is taking place on one of the magical trees, the two friends end up in a nearby forest where a rival mage meets up with them. He possesses the skeletal remains of their friendly stranded island mage who they’ve had contact with the entire time, and reveals that he sent her back in time so that she wouldn't be involved in the war. What follows is a sprawling argument about what actually happened to the princess and the possibility of getting her off of the island and back to the present.


An immediate plothole can be found in the communication devices used by the friends and the princess, being two identical dolls that act as telephones (it’s magic, don’t question it). After establishing that the island itself isn’t a bubble of altered time, it becomes impossible for the princess to send out her doll in a bottle, count four months on her side before establishing contact, while the protagonists find it and begin communication two years later. Another is established when the rival mage argues that the barrel in which the princess’ current remains are held is the same as one on the island with her. After the friends tell the princess to carve something on the barrel to prove it, the barrel shows the carving in the present day as a pre-established marking. The simple solution to sabotage the show’s logic on how the spacetime continuum works would be to make the princess carve more and watch the present barrel remain the same, but of course the show doesn't do that and ignores this inconsistency as well.


The enemy clan’s motivations and use of magic from the other clans become virtually nonsensical during this time. Workarounds to the conundrum of the princess in the past, some of which would actually fix a poorly done script, are abandoned as pointless so that the show can carry out the intended problematic narrative. Eventually, the protagonists find a way to bring the princess back to the present by letting her resonate with her present remains, to which we question the powerful and knowledgeable mage of reasoning and logic as to why she didn’t think of that valid solution earlier. All of these developments are completely spoonfed to the audience as though the show's weak plot twist was too much to handle, as characters stand frozen in position for the entire scene, only switching places quickly halfway through, all while the scene is sandwiched between minute long intervals of pointless flashbacks and the military battle going on next door. After two hours of this, the princess comes back to the present that she appeared to be in anyway, the annoying enemy mage feels incompetent, and an underwhelming midpoint finale comes and goes without our investment. A boring, pointless waste of time indeed.


After the script shoots itself in the face with a gatling gun we still have five more hours to get through. One recap episode later and we find ourselves in a world where the tree of Genesis takes over, kills a ton of the world population, but at least things are peaceful for now. Firstly, the once great animation is reduced to completely regular visuals for a 2013 action anime. The continuing story becomes an utter bore, as main characters fall to usual tropes and side characters and villains form a commonplace protagonist group that lacks any personality or presence onscreen. The conflict between which magical tree to side with, once smartly left ambiguous, is rendered worthless as the writers lazily pick one tree as everyone’s common enemy. If you can believe it, the semi-gritty magical battles are reduced to a sentai plotline that even Samurai Flamenco would point and laugh at while a complete stranger is brought in to be the deus ex miracle that fixes everything for a happy ending. 


Despite a near irredeemable downward spiral story structure, the show did retain a couple satisfying elements. One is the relationship between the main protagonist and the girlfriend, which felt original and unique. Both of them were very cynical around each other like they were stuck together and it felt more genuine than a generic romance that could have been written. Though the protagonist was a bore, the girlfriend had an aura of tranquility and wisdom that made her the most memorable character in the cast. The other is a fun second plot twist during the third act which was built up and executed much better than the show's first. Aside from these and the first few episodes that do well to pull viewers in right away, the negatives drag the anime so far down that it doesn't even attempt to climb back up in the end. 


To close, the last thing to talk about is how Blast Of Tempest undeniably loves Shakespeare. Fans praise the anime because they say that it felt like one of Willy’s works, although the only factors to support that conclusion are the constant verbalizations from the characters who draw parallels from their situation to Hamlet or The Tempest. Saying that your story is just like Shakespeare does not magically make your story Shakespearean, that’s a no-brainer. Nowhere in this bombshell of a shounen turned sentai narrative are there thematic elements that warrant a legitimate comparison to William’s work, and I suggest that fans look to Berserk for more fruitful inspiration from the playwright.

Would a peaceful world without crime and war be worth the prize of a billion people? The show not only provide thought provoking themes with the drama, but also with the plot. The way the character used the quotes and how they debated, philosophized and argued about them, was very interesting and had many times a connection to the plot. Thanks to that I really started to get was these old dramas really was all about; loss, regret, anger, love, hope, numbness, strength, doubt, madness, despair, sadness, fate, acceptance, conclusion, helplessness and of course revenge - expressed in words very beautifully. "Zetsuen no Tempest" contain all these components and plays them out brilliantly in form of it´s characters and it´s story.


Which brings me to the characters. They embody these feelings and emotions into their personalities and actions - this is how a great drama shall be done. I think it´s kind of bold to take Shakespeare´s work and making an anime like this, but for me it was a slam-and-dunk. The main characters are really something else in this show. 


Let´s start with Mahiro for example - He has an arrogant and nonchalant personality, and when faced with the murder/loss of his sister he broke down. He was left with regret, anger and hate. And of course those feelings lead to a desire for revenge. Other when those feelings Mahiro becomes emotionally numb. He doesn´t care what he has to do get his revenge - even if he has to become  merciless. And all that feels believable when delivered as it done in "Zetsuen". Because Mahiro isn´t a static character, his character develops a lot during the show. Aika is technically dead throughout the whole show, but are a main character (if not "THE" main character) with a lot of influence on the plot and all the other characters. She is a very odd and serious 15-year old. She only reads Shakespeare and love to quote them - but almost always from just "Hamlet" and "The Tempest". She always use them to make philosophical point - she has a tremendous influence over Mahiro and Yoshino. Akia gives away a aura of calm acceptance - it´s like nothing can disturb her emotionally. The origin of this this calm acceptance is one of the mystical tones "Zetsuen" has. Yoshino is a very intelligent, shy and kind person, and after his secret girlfriend Akia´s death he becomes trapped in a void of numb acceptance. He can´t grieve his lost love openly, and suffers in silence. Yoshino is a very mysterious character, because he never seem faced by anything around him how horrible then it may be. It´s like something died inside him then Aika died. He doesn´t see the point in taking revenge - the dead is dead and can never come back. This leads to many heated discussions with Mahiro. And just like Mahiro, Yoshino isn´t a static character - he also develop nicely and have some of the shows strongest emotional moments. Hakaze is very confident young woman with eminence powers - she´s a magician with a huge responsibility on her shoulders. She´s a leader and a princess out in her fingertips, and are seldom doubting her self. But fate has a pretty ruff path layed out for her - she has to face many challenges and falls into despair. Her interactions with Yoshino is able her to find new strength. I really enjoyed her stoic and intelligent personality. Even during her short kudare phase she was able to analyze things in a very self sacrificing and objective way. She embodies the word straight forward in a refreshing way.


As for the side characters they all have a part to play, but after amazing entrances they do not develop much at all. They are for shore not boring, but so much more could had been done with them. I would have liked to see them in more personally situations, and seen them interact more with each other and the main character in the same way. Because the main characters was so strong, more had to be done with them to make them really shine. This is just a thought due, so don´t mined this to much. It definitely doesn´t ruin the show in any way.   


"Zetsuen" is produced by studio Bones, and the art animation is outstanding. It´s almost flawless. Character designs is great - it´s towards the pretty corner but done very nicely. The thing that stood out was the characters eyes. The way they could express 100s of emotions just with their eyes is masterly done. It suite the dramatic theme like a hand in a glove. The backgrounds are almost life like - we are getting gorgeous sun settings, after noon lights in a park, city silhouettes, and fields on the country side. Everything is breathtakingly beautiful. The motions of the characters are smooth and fluid, without any hint of jerkiness. The coloration and light setting are always on spot. Really a visual masterpiece. The magic scenes are fantastic - with light and colors that really giving the magic  life. And the action scenes - most of them is masterpieces in them self. Fluid motions, nice angles and badass techniques. They are slowed down and speed up in just the right moments. Some of them are the best I seen.


The music used for this show was absolutely wonderful. Intense violins and dramatic classical music really lifted "Zetsuen" to the heights. The tension in the scenes sky rockets with the well suited soundtrack. The show has often a heavy and dramatic feeling to it, and the soundtrack really brings that out in full potential. I will listen to this a very long time. I watched subbed and man did the VA´s do a fantastic job. Not only did they bring the characters to life but they were the characters. Absolutely amazing. They managed to bring out the essence of the character, and their voices suited their characters very well. I liked both OP´s but the first one I thought suited the show more. Both was fast going but the first one had a bit darker feeling to it. It´s was really good - I always took the time to watch that one. The ED´s are of the slower sad kind. Both suiting both nothing prize worthy. 


"Zetsuen" has one of the strongest opening episodes I ever encountered, it really caught me of guard. It made the promise that the show would be great, and it held that promise to me. Some small things just made it out of a masterpiece for me, but I´m truly happy with the show. It´had me interested, invested, intrigued, exited and awed. The Shakespeare influences was done very well in my opinion, and brought the old classical dramas in to this century in an intersecting way. I enjoyed "Zetsuen" a hell of a lot, and the strong and impactful characters is gonna stay in my memories for a long time. If you ever lost someone close to you or know someone that has, much of the emotions and actions the character feel or do makes perfect sense. The loss of the person that you loved the most can really break a person - and how can one fined meaning in a world that don´t make sense. That journey is a very relatable one, and I think the show portrays this very well. From start to end - all the emotions that makes up such a journey are there in the show. I will for shore rewatch this time to time, I believe I will fined new details every time. The fantastic story, explosive characters, brilliant animation together with a wonderful soundtrack truly makes this show great in my eyes.

The moment I caught sight of this anime title, "Zetsuen no Tempest", I knew that it was an anime I could not miss. I was not mistaken.
If I could compare ZnT to a graph, I would say it is best described as a sin curve ranging from 0 to pi(n-shaped). It gets off to a slow start, and may leave you wondering whether to just drop it after the first episode. Well, I'm saying it now, don't. That's going to be a big mistake. Our pair of young male protagonists at first glance appears to be two idiots who are slightly damaged in the head,with one guy making infrequent declarations of vengeance and the other guy who shows no sign of surprise/emotion upon seeing his fellow students turned into inanimate black metal. Well, I'll be damned, but this was in fact all planned.


Afterward, we are introduced to a clan of magic-wielders known as the Kusaribe clan. One faction comprises Samon and majority of the clan, the other faction is Princess Hakaze, the fiery clan leader who was trapped by Samon on an isolated island, and our two male protagonists, whose help she had recruited. From then onward, the story picked up and the action escalated as the conflict between the two sides increased, with both sides running out of time. The mystery thickened, the atmosphere got heavier, and the tension was palpable as the two sides faced off. Now we gradually come to the realization that in fact the initial impression of the protagonists were exactly planned to pique our curiosity. Why are these two guys like that? What happened in their past? With us the viewers dying to know in front of the screen, the director could be aptly described as a skillful conductor, controlling the flow of the music to  be sometimes slow and methodical, other times furious and powerful, yet always tantalizing. Combine the intriguing story with the intelligent action sequences(sorry to disappoint, shounen fans, this is not your run-of-the-mill "it's over 9000!!" let's-see-who-can-summon-larger-fireballs kind of fights), and Bones living up to their reputation for quality animation, and I dare say that the anime is every bit as good as the Shakespearean plays it pays tribute to.


With a catch, of course. That's only for the first half. In the second half of the anime, things sort of dwindle down and become less interesting. As conflicts resolve and the mystery becomes clear, so too does the tension and force that contributed to the impact of the first half. Not only that, we get introduced to another character who plays an important role but is far more annoying, idiotic, and shounen-ish than the two protagonists. Well, I suppose the message that power and responsibility are sometimes forced upon us was made pretty clear. In the end, the last 2 or 3 episodes were pretty predictable and became somewhat of a drag to me.


All in all though, if you have a taste for intrigue, mystery, action, and appreciate attention to details, ZnT is an anime you should not miss.(Overall 8.5)

Summary: Zetsuen no Tempest is an anime that starts out with some great build-up in the first half of the show, only to fall completely on its face during the second half. Nevertheless, the anime is good enough to warrant a watch.
Longer review:
Story/Plot
They should’ve called this anime ‘Plot Twist Mania’.
The plot has so many twists and turns that it’s almost impossible to predict what’s going to happen, at least for the first half of the show. After that, however, you come to expect the twists, to the point where they either become (even more) nonsensical or even predictable. So nonsensical, in fact, that at somepoint, the anime just literally gives up and goes: 'Aliens. It was aliens'.


This show suffers from something I like to call ‘Sword Art Online Disease’, where the second half of the series is so vastly different in setting and tone than the first half that it becomes inferior to the first half of the series. Though this case is not as bad as Sword Art Online’s was (that second half was unwatchable), this one is not all that great, either.


During the first half of the show we are presented to a world of magic that’s, quite frankly, awesome. The idea for the apocalypse (the world’s logic will be erased), is very original. It has this very nice air of mystery and misery around it, which I really love. The plot was solid, even if the pay-off was a little too much talking and not enough showing. 


The second half of the show goes for a much lighter tone. Both the characters and the plot were heavily simplified and it just didn’t sit well with me. You had such an awesome buildup to just... kinda fall flat.


Due to the second half, the story was reduced from a good to a mediocre one. Still, it's servicable, as long as you ignore the insane plottwists (ALIENS!).



The Characters


What I liked about the characters, at least during the first half of the show, was that there weren’t really any stereotypes in the cast. At least, not the stereotypes you usually see.


The main character is Takigawa Yoshino. Yoshino was introduced as a sort toned down version of Shiroe from Log Horizon – a guy who is, generally, nice, but will not hesitate to choose the most effective way of executing his plans, even if it’s the most brutal one. He’s very smart and has this air mystery~ around him. There were constantly hints that he was actually not as nice as he looked and acted, but the show never really showed that darker side of him, which just kind of annoyed me. 


The second main character is Fuwa Mahiro. He is, no other way to describe it, a fucking badass. He is very much the anti-hero of this show – he doesn’t care what happens to him, his friends, or even the world, as long as he gets to have revenge for his sister. And he’s not just all bark, too, he also has the strength and wits to back him up. He is very impulsive, though, which brings him into trouble quite a lot. 


The third and last (living) main character is Hakaze. Hakaze is the princess of the Kusaribe Clan and also the strongest mage on this planet. Even though they could’ve easily turned her into just fanservice (she still kind of is, to be honest), or even a damsel in distress, the show decides to actually show her some respect. Hakaze is a stubborn mage who does not let anyone tell her what to do. Even after basically being rendered useless on an island, she refuses to back off and does what she can to continue thwarting the Tree of Exodus and Samon. She had the potential to be the strongest female character I’ve seen in a long time...


...and then the second half came around.


During the second half of the show, all coolness just seemed to be sucked out of the characters. Yoshino becomes some sort of fish (not kidding, that’s his expression most of the time), Mahiro’s presence becomes heavily toned down and he almost does a one-eighty character flip and Hakaze is reduced to a motherfucking tsundere. A. Motherfucking. TSUNDERE!! The most overused trope in all of anime, this amazing character is reduced to the most overused trope in anime! 


It really annoys me, since all these characters had so much potential and it just lays there now, unused, and just... ARGH!


*deep breath*


Okay. Moving on.


The only character I had a problem with before the second half rolled around was Aika. Fuwa Aika is Mahiro’s sister WHO IS NOT RELATED BY BLOOD (we all know where this is going *sigh*) and seems to speak in exposition or something. Even though she is dead by the time the show starts, we constantly get flashbacks to her from both Yoshino and Mahiro, who both make her out to be some sort of angel (even if they deny it). She really doesn’t have much of a character outside of being the biggest Mary Sue I’ve seen in a long time before, ironically, the second half.


Even though the second half is where the show takes a nosedive, it seems to lift Aika into the air. She actually becomes pretty interesting and, since we get to see her from someone else’s perspective then the two guys that are in love with her, she gets a much more nuanciated image. It’s still not enough to make up for constantly speaking in exposition, though. Seriously, it’s annoying. Nobody talks like that.


The minor characters are probably my favorite thing, though. And then especially the antagonists (for the first half, naturally). The reason for that is that they are human. 


The majority of the side characters are, in reality, very weak and prone to panic. Especially the main villain, Samon, is like this. Normally, I would bash this and call them bad villains, but this time, it’s not like that. What makes them good villains is that the show doesn’t even try to make them threatening. They portray them as humans with human emotions and human mistakes. They’re honestly doing what they think is best, and have very good reasons for it. They don’t like what they’re doing, but do it nonetheless, without the obligatory ‘Should I shouldn’t I’ moment most villains have. This is something I like – a lot. 


Overall, the characters had a lot of potential, but fell flat on their face in the execution of that potential. Which saddens me, because I’d honestly want to see them in their full-fledged form.



Animation


The animation looks AMAZING. Especially the magic looks beautiful, both in design and movement. It’s very traditional, yet has a fresh air around it. The rest of the fight scenes are also very well executed and look solid. The only exception to this are the fight scenes between trees, but that’s not necessarily because the animation is bad, but more because they’re... well... trees fighting. Come on. I cannot take that seriously. 


I also love the art. It has a lot of dark shades in the first half of the show, yet also manages to make the colors stand out perfectly. I like it.


Summary: the animation is Bones. Of course it’s good.



Music/Sound


The soundtrack is beautiful on its own, but sometimes it tries to overshadow the animation/story, which I don’t like. With the existence of the first opening this is all forgiven, though, as it is amazing.


The only thing that bothers me a bit is the voice actor for Tetsuma. His voice just sounds unnatural with the character design. Later on in the series, this stopped bothering me though, probably because I just got used to it.


Al in all, despite some minor annoyances, the sound/music department is solid.



Conclusion


Zestuen no Tempest was an anime that had a lot of potential, but due to some problems in the second half, ended up neglecting most of that potential. This saddens me, for it could’ve been a lot better.


Still, though, as I begrudingly admit, this anime is solid. The first half is absolutely amazing, and even if the second half falls flat in comparison to the first, it still has some solid characters and plotlines. If that had been an anime on its own, I probably wouldn’t have had much of a problem with it, it’s more because the first half is so awesome that it irritates me. 


All in all, this anime is at least worth a watch.

Story: The beginning of the story is about a mage chick named Hakaze who gets stranded on an island. She employs the help of two friends, Mahiro and Yoshino, and communicates with them via magic, voodoo-doll walkie-talkies. Mahiro’s motive for helping is to find the person who killed his younger sister, Aika. While Yoshino, Aika’s secret boyfriend, just kinda wants to tag along. The main goal of their adventure is to stop the awakening of a terribly destructive tree god. The series is also extremely flashback-heavy and details Mahiro/Yoshino’s friendship and the secret relationship Yoshino had with Aika.
The story didn’t grab me. Whenit came down to it, the main bad guy was a tree and the two main protagonists spend the entire anime moping. Come on, we all know how annoying it is to be around someone who can’t get over an ex. Now multiply that by two and put them together. The series as a whole lacked action and urgency. After Episode 12 I really lost sight of what the hell everyone was trying to do. They basically took a hiatus from the plot. This was used to develop a one-sided romance, answer a few questions about people’s pasts and introduce a couple new characters that I didn’t care about. I’m sorry, but if you want to build a murder mystery into the plot that’s great but don’t put the whole plot on hold to do it. Literally billions of people are dying, cities are being destroyed, and we are getting worked up about 1 girl’s death? Some perspective please.


On the topic of Aika and the murder mystery they kind of messed that part up. First, they spent way too much time focusing on it. By about episode 14 I had heard enough about Aika and by episode 17 I was becoming progressively more nauseated with every sentimental flashback. As for the actual mystery and suspense part they built an intriguing story only to knock it down with a weird, irrational twist.

I think the only part of this anime that really stood out was when we find out the ‘who/what/when/where/why/how’ about how Hazake got stranded. It was actually really well done and could have been a great springboard for Yoshino’s character. Unfortunately the story flopped on its belly after that and those few episodes were as good as it got.


I think anime can be a tool to address philosophical questions, realities of human nature, moral truths etc.. Tempest has a lot of fatalistic themes built into it which I don’t’ mind but they didn’t do it well. I finished the series feeling like there was some vague attempt at a deeper message but ultimately I was unsure of what they were trying to convey. By the end I was just irritated at the characters I was supposed to care about.  


Characters: 

I don’t know anything about Japanese courtship but god damn those teens were passive aggressive. Sneaking around, setting up fake encounters, pretending to hate one another to throw people off. It’s like an unspoken rule that you can’t just sit down and talk about a problem you have to put it off and hide it until it explodes. I guess it made the love triangle entertaining but it also made the dilemmas difficult to relate to and the characters difficult to admire. 


The way the characters reacted to emotional situations seemed abnormal and very blunted. Yoshino’s reactions and thought process remained super passive and detached. Many characters were either 1 dimensional or inconsistent. By the end of the series I didn’t know what Yoshino stood for or why. Btw, if you watch this anime, keep an eye out for the ‘video message’, I found it to be a lot more creepy than touching. Who the fuck would get turned on by that? 


As a general rule, characters should behave rationally and in their own best interests or according to their ideals. If they're going take the painful or difficult path it should be because there is no easier or simpler option. That's just good writing. You create a plot hole when the audience can think of a much simpler solution to a problem the protagonists are struggling with. Needless self-sacrifice makes for cheap emotional porn. I loved LotR. It was an epic trilogy, full of amazing battles, struggles and sacrifices but why couldn’t the eagles have just dropped the ring in Mt Doom from the start? Tempest is full of shit like that cept without the epicness.  


Art: Extremely good art. I need to say it. I need to mention Yoshino's character design. He is one of the most feminine looking male character I’ve seen. He has a pixie haircut and wears hairclips. I kept mistaking him for a girl. You can take that information however you want.


Sound: The intros were mediocre but the music was very good and helped create a sad and haunting atmosphere.

Overall: Not wowed. The murder mystery was kind of a flop for me. The action was average at best. The story left many unanswered questions. The characters were inconsistent.


Love/Romance: They love a dead girl. There’s some stuff on the side that’s pretty awkwardly done and completely one-sided.

Blood/Gore: Not too much actually.

Sex/Nudity: A bit of fan service and cleavage.

About the STORY
It’s different in a sense of how the flow of story is done! It’s definitely not the typical or traditional way of storytelling. Not to mention that the first half is kind of in the heavy side and the second half is lighter. But it is also true that the first half is a lot more exciting than the second part where there are more flashbacks. One of the most interesting parts of the series is the monologues particularly from Hamlet and The Tempest by William Shakespeare. And the bad side is, the series’ storyline might become too boring for some who prefermore action than talking as there are countless moments for arguments or showdown of reasoning rather than something really happening.


About the CHARACTERS

The two main characters are like combinations of the typical characteristics of shounen series protagonists; one is physically strong type character and the other is the smart type which makes their tandem great for the type of the story the series has. It’s interesting that a dead character can manipulate the story so much. And almost all the characters have interesting roles which is quite rare as there are countless of series with huge number of forgettable characters.


About the ANIMATION

As one of the latest series of today, it’s really a great thing that the animation, particularly the action, is leveled up. There’s amazing details in the fight scenes which makes it even cooler and exciting. Plus, the character’s design is also something to look forward to.


About the ENJOYMENT

 For someone who loves literature like myself; having Hamlet and The Tempest as the basis for the story is really amazing. It is no doubt one of the most exciting series of today but that is mostly from the first part and some in the ending. However, the start of the second part gradually makes it less and less interesting and exciting. It is more of the comical approach which is so different from how it started. Nevertheless, I still feel contented. it still definitely left an impression with me.

Before I begin my tentative first review, I would like to say that as a huge anime fan and veteran watcher, very few series have given me an exhilarating and intriguing experience as Zetsuen no Tempest.  Now obviously, as Zetsuen no Tempest is Shounen in nature, it's target demographic is a very large, young male and teenage audience, and as one such male teen myself, that indubitably has influenced my perception of this series.  Also, Zetsuen no Tempest is heavily influencedby William Shakespeare's "Hamlet" and "The Tempest" and having read both plays, my perception and reception of this series will be further biased towards one view.  Nevertheless, despite these permeating factors, Zetsuen no Tempest, in my opinion, is one series that can appeal to any type of audience due to its eclectic range of themes, concepts, and perhaps most importantly, conflicts. Like "Hamlet" and "The Tempest," Zetsuen no Tempest is a story of revenge set in a world where magic exists.  Like Hamlet and Prospero, in the first half of the series, one of the main protagonists goes on a quest for revenge: a quest to find and take vengeance upon the person who killed his sister.  Whilst on his quest, he and his friend (the other main protagonist) see that the world is crumbling around them and that people are turning to stone in cities.  During their journey, they question the irrationality and the (sometimes lack of) logic of the world several times: Why did my sister have to be killed?  Why is the world like this?  Question like these force the audience to reexamine themselves and the world they live in; to question justice and nature and how illogical the world they inhabit can be.  The logic of the world is governed by the Tree of Genesis, and the Kusaribe clan, the clan that can use magic in Zetsuen no Tempest, is responsible for guarding it.  By contrast, the Tree of Exodus is said to oppose the logic of the world and will be responsible for bringing about its destruction.  Here, the theme of duality is emphasized: Genesis vs. Exodus, Logic vs. Irrationality, etc.  Similarly, throughout the series, flashbacks go back to the main protagonist's sister who always quotes from "Hamlet" and "The Tempest" when speaking with him or the other main protagonist.  In those flashbacks, we also see the theme of duality emphasized in the juxtaposition of both of Shakespeare's plays: "Hamlet" is a tragedy where the main characters, save Horatio, die in the end, whereas "The Tempest" is a happy story where Prospero rightfully reclaims the throne from Alfonso, with no deaths occurring in the end.  The theme of duality present in the series is perhaps the most important one as it plays an integral role in the second half of the series which I will explain in my next paragraph.


The story then takes a shift in tone and style with the second half of the series.  The first half focuses on adventure, and fighting, whereas the second half takes a more light-hearted, slice of life style.  In the second half, the Tree of Genesis has emerged and has ended most of the world's problems: famines have been eliminated, no more wars, no diseases, etc.  However, at the same time, the Tree of Exodus has started to grow and has chosen a Mage of Exodus to be its avatar.  In the later parts of the second half, the truth behind Aika's death is revealed and that the Tree of Genesis is what would truly bring about the end of the world and that the Tree of Exodus has the power to stop it.  With this revelation, the Kusaribe clan and the main characters realize that just blindly following what they were told and just following old traditions would have led to their doom.  In this sense, Samon, who advocated for the resurrection of the Tree of Exodus, actually served as the true voice of reason and free will after the fact.  In the end, the Tree of Genesis is destroyed and humanity is back to where it started before with the problems plaguing it before now returned.  


The main thing to garner from the story is the concept of duality.  Duality is seen in the conflict between the two trees, the endings of both of Shakespeare's plays that are referenced heavily, determinism and free will, etc.  While Aika's death in and of itself is a tragedy that draws parallel with the deaths of the characters in "Hamlet," the ending of Zetsuen no Tempest is one of happiness and freedom that parallels with "The Tempest": a world no longer ruled by the Tree of Genesis and where humanity can walk and think on its own feet.  Undoubtedly, the beginning of the story can seem crazy and confusing and too scattered to understand at first, but as one continues experiencing the wild ride of Zetsuen no Tempest, one will begin to connect all the pieces and see how everything comes together beautifully in the end.


Art: 8
